subject: Languages
title: Language Prescriptivism vs. Descriptivism
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Language Prescriptivism vs. Descriptivism.

hook.text: Should you say 'who' or 'whom'? It depends whether you ask a prescriptivist or a descriptivist.

buildup.text: Prescriptivists set rules for 'correct' language. Descriptivists study how people actually speak.

discovery.text: Most grammar 'rules' â€” don't split infinitives, don't end with prepositions â€” were invented in the 1700s.

twist.text: These rules were modeled on Latin grammar and imposed on English â€” a language that works completely differently.

climax.text: Modern linguists are descriptivists: they study language as it is, not as someone thinks it should be.

punchline.text: Breaking a grammar rule doesn't corrupt a language. It's how languages evolve.

quiz.question: What is the difference between prescriptivism and descriptivism?
options: Prescriptivists set rules; descriptivists study how people actually speak
Prescriptivists study slang; descriptivists write dictionaries
Prescriptivism is modern; descriptivism is ancient
